Note: This currently seems to work for Windows but struggles with installation on Linux! This documented error happens on the server: https://arrow.apache.org/docs/r/articles/install.html#package-failed-to-build-c-dependencies

description: This is required if you want to use the variableinspector
comment: https://github.com/lckr/jupyterlab-variableInspector#requirements-for-r-functionality

Why do I added this? Check why exactly this has to be installed. Current hypothesis: This is needed for devtools.This package is necessary to be able to install R-packages from GitHub. This package is not available in Linux

description: Adds a variable inspector to jupyterlab
comment: Optional addon for jupyterlab that adds a variable explorer. I couldn't install it on Windows. See issues from JohannesWiesner on GitHub (you can filter for my name in the repo on GitHub). But on Linux it works fine

description: Installing R-packages from GitHub
comment: This package is necessary to be able to install R-packages from GitHub (aka. that can not be installed using conda or CRAN). After installed you can run commands like devtools::install_github()

description: An IDE for R
comment: Currently not recommended to install R-studio in a conda environment because this will downgrade your R-version to 3.x.x. The current alternative is jupyter-lab. This should be checked regularily to see if a new update was released. Maybe in the future it wil become in a more recent version in conda-forge?

description: An alternative IDE to RStudio, which might be faster and offers a more pythonic experience
the R programming language itself
Package to conduct sparse canonical correlation analysis
comment: Why do I added this? This is the same as install.packages('PMA') that can also be found in this spreadsheet? Choose either this package or install PMA package with CRAN, but not both. If you can succesfully use the gemmr package and if you can rerun Xia et al. script, then you don't have to use install.package('PMA'')

distro provides information about the OS distribution it runs on, such as a reliable machine-readable ID, or version information.
comment: This package is useful to detect on which specific distro your current python script is running. For example you might want to run the script both on your personal machine and on the server. In this case paths might change and you want to have an option to automatically change paths by detecting the OS

description: abagen lets you get information about gene receptor densities using the Allen Human Brain Atlas and a custom atlas of your choice
